awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the 2023 offering of the Summer Geometry Initiative (SGI), to be held online July 10-August 18, 2023.  SGI is a six-week program supporting a cohort of undergraduates and early master's students in entering research in geometry processing.  In the first week of SGI, participants will attend hands-on tutorials introducing the theory and practice of geometry processing; no background or previous experience is necessary.  During the remaining weeks, participants will work in teams on research projects led by faculty and research scientists in this discipline, while attending talks and other sessions led by visiting researchers.  SGI aims to broaden the pool of students applying for PhD programs and employment related to geometry processing and applied mathematics more broadly; it has a long track record of increasing the size and diversity of the pool of new members of the community.

Geometry processing has a long history of breakthrough developments that have guided design of 3D tools for computer vision, additive manufacturing, scientific computing, and other disciplines.  Algorithms for geometry processing combine ideas from disciplines including differential geometry, topology, physical simulation, statistics, and optimization.  The tutorials and research in SGI bring SGI Fellows and other participants up-to-date with state-of-the-art ideas in this emerging discipline and introduce them to leaders in the field with whom they collaborate on exploratory research projects.

Website:  https://sgi.mit.edu/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Support from this grant was used to continue the Summer Geometry Initiative (SGI) in 2023, a summer program introducing undergraduates and early master's students to research in applied geometry.

SGI 2023 took place during six weeks in summer 2023.  The program supported a cohort of 32 SGI Fellows, who participated in the program full-time; an additional cohort of ~20 students were invited to participate in the initial week.  The first week of the program featured a set of daily tutorials and interactive exercises intended to introduce participants to key theoretical concepts and software tools in geometry processing research, with no assumption on past experience in the field (beyond basic linear algebra, calculus, and programming skills).  The remaining five weeks were dedicated to research experiences, mostly 1-2 week research collaborations led by top faculty and research scientists in the field.

SGI 2023 was overwhelmingly successful, exceeding expectations for the technical and broader impact-oriented aims of the program.  Some highlights are included below:

  • A central aim of SGI is to bring a diverse set of new members to the geometry processing community.  82.8% of SGI Fellows (among survey respondents) self-identified as members of an underrepresented group in computing or mathematical sciences, and numerous countries were represented among the fellows.
  • After the program, many SGI Fellows reported that they were likely to pursue graduate education (MS, PhD) in geometry processing and related fields.  PhD admissions are ongoing as of this report, and many 2023 Fellows reported submitting applications to top programs.  Several SGI faculty mentors reported they were likely to recruit SGI Fellows for their research groups.
  • Similarly to the previous offerings, SGI 2023 was held completely online.  The program pioneered techniques in online research-based education that we plan to use over the longer term.
  • MIT EECS has used SGI as a model program for efforts promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) among applicants for our graduate program.  It is now included in MIT EECS's strategic plan for DEI efforts moving forward.
  • Several research projects launched during SGI continued beyond the end of the program, and we are currently seeing resulting papers submitted to top conferences and journals in our discipline.

Readers are invited to visit the SGI 2023 blog for write-ups by SGI Fellows describing some of the many projects they completed: http://summergeometry.org/sgi2023

Data collection among the participants (Fellows and mentors) reflected many of the positive points above.  Example student feedback includes the following:

  • "The tutorial week was amazing. It was amazing how much better I got at programming over the course of a week. It was specific to geometry processing, butthe skills I gained could be applied to many different problems/ research. I found the problems to be very difficult but not to the point where I felt discouraged. The volunteers were so helpful and did a great job of answering questions and encouraging us."
  • "The SGI research projects were a valuable learning experience for me. I was fortunate to collaborate with excellent mentors on three different projects. Research is a challenging and rewarding process that requires a lot of time and effort, but we managed to use our time efficiently and produce meaningful results in a short period. The projects helped me explore new domains and test my skills and commitment."
  • "SGI and geometry processing is a very welcoming research community. I would love to pursue my graduate study in geometry processing in the coming year."
  • "Thank you so much for organizing thin amazing program, I truly enjoyed my time in the program, met some wonderful individuals, and learned a great deal about geometry processing considering that I knew zilch about the topic before the program."
  • "I wish to express my gratitude towards Justin and all organizers for taking this initiative of providing exposure to students, especially underepresented groups in the field of geometric processing. Although I previously knew many of the mentors through the papers, I didn't have the courage to approach them for a PhD cause I felt I don't have a good enough profile. SGI has provided me confidence and the platform to approach them in person for which I am really thankful!"

Planning for SGI 2024 is underway.  Due in large part to the success of the previous offerings, the latest version has received overwhelming interest among students who wish to participate as well as faculty who wish to mentor participants in the program.


Last Modified: 01/01/2024
Modified by: Justin M Solomon
